item.description:
The fantasy of becoming filthy rich by building a pyramid scheme is now a fun family game. The outcome is known only at the very end. Rules are simple, and the game is unpredictable. There is no bankruptcy, and you are in the game until the money is counted when the game is over. Each player develops and controls schemes to make as much money as possible. The get-rich schemes is completely illegal in all civilized societies, including all 50 states of the USA. We produce this game so that you can use the power of the pyramid to make that incredible fortune.
—description from the publisher

Includes a free game called "Annexaton" in the same box.

A strategy game where players compete time to survive .

In a dystopian reality, a nuclear war has distorted the geomagnetic field of the earth and has caused gravity instability. The atmosphere is now filled with metal shavings and only a few humans have survived by forming four energy civilizations of gravity, antigravity, vortex and spin. Together they managed to create the Magnes Omni,a magnetic armillary cog, that works like a time machine. This project of physics will help them travel in time and change the actions of the past that led to today’s unbearable living conditions. The Magnes Omni needs magnets, small black holes and energy cogs to operate and produces only one of the energies of the civilizations. Consequently, only one civilization can unlock the mechanism of the Magnes Omni and travel back in time to fulfill its purpose. Which one is going to be the first, that will manage to catch Omni's angular momentum?

Compete to unlock an Armillary Cog.
Strategize using Magnetism, Black Holes and Energy Cogs.
Fight against time to catch the angular momentum.

RIG InterGalactic is a tabletop combat game played with customizable spaceship models called RIGs. 

The Guild of RIG Pilots have openings for new members and have posted a challenge to everyone with the means to battle other pilots. Pilots battle it out by drawing from constructed Decks and playing cards to activate System Discs to have various types of weapon and special abilities, which are then physically launched from the RIGs. Earn victory points after each successful battle to eventually be accepted into the Guild. Gain rank within the Guild and with rank comes rewards.

Five different RIGs (buildable spaceship miniatures) can be customized by mounting the parts the way players want and the ships can also be mixed to build a totally new RIG.
 
Configure your RIG by installing various types of Platforms into your RIG's Modules and construct your Deck according to the installed Platform Systems.

Gameplay:
- Setup

 Players roll their dice to determine who will be the first Active Player (AP). The player with the highest roll starts as the AP.
 Starting with the Non-Active Player (NAP), players take turns to place 1 part of any Obstacle set on the Battlespace. Take turns to place a maximum of 8 parts each. 
 Drop a System Disc (SD) from shoulder height in the area between your elbow and torso onto the Battlespace. Where it stops is your Arrival Point. Drop the SD again if it leaves the Battlespace or stopped on top of an obstacle. 
 Place your RIG over your Arrival Point in any orientation.
 Shuffle your Deck and place it close to the edge of the Battlespace.
 Players draw 7 cards: choose up to 5 for your starting hand and place the rest on the bottom of your Deck.
 The game starts when the players are done selecting a starting hand.
 Your RIG has 20 armor.




- Turn structure: (AP and NAP play simultaneously)
The AP as determined at setup: (Proceed in any order and announce your intention) 

 Has 2 moves while In Space. 
 May draw 2 cards to a maximum of a 5-card hand size while In Space. 
 May play any number of In Space abilities while In Space. 
 May play 1 App at any time. 
 May attack once where In Battle abilities are played. 
 Declare end of the turn as soon as you've done the above or at any time during your turn.




The NAP: (Proceed in any order and announce your intention)

 May draw 1 card to a maximum of a 5-card hand size while In Space.
 May play any number of In Space abilities while In Space. 
 May play 1 App at any time.
 Becomes the AP when the current AP declares the end of turn and when you're done playing your cards or choose to proceed.




Victory conditions:
1. The game ends when a player's RIG is destroyed or after the turn where a player's Deck runs out. 
2. The player with the surviving RIG wins the game.
3. The player with the most armor after the turn where a player's Deck runs out wins the game. 
4. If the armor amounts are equal after the game, the players must place their RIGs 30cm apart and load 1 SD each. The players launch simultaneously. The player who achieves the closest Proximity wins the game. A Direct or Surface Hit is an automatic loss. Relaunch for Proximity if both players scored a Direct or Surface Hit.

Glossary:
Battlespace.
The game can be played on any smooth surface, like a glass or polished wood table or a neoprene tabletop gaming mat.

System Discs (SD).
Play cards to activate SDs that have been physically loaded into your RIG's base.

Move.
Draw and release the trigger to launch a loaded SD from your RIG into the Battlespace. Move in a straight line and over obstacles and place your RIG directly over the SD where it stopped.

In Space.

 You don't need a target. 
 Play as many In Space abilities as you're able to.
 When playing an In Space ability and it directly affects your opponent, the player that places the card on the Battlespace first plays first. Roll the Initiative dice if there is a dispute, highest roll plays first. 




In Battle.

 Launch an SD at an enemy RIG to target it.
 Check attack initiative: Both players roll their dice and the attacking player adds 1 to their rolled amount. Both players re-roll their dice if the final amounts are equal.
 Highest roll gains the initiative.
 The player with initiative plays an In Battle ability first. 
 The opponent plays an In Battle ability as a counter. 




Direct Hit.
Resolve when your launched SD stops underneath your opponent's base. The SD has to be totally underneath the base to be valid.

Surface Hit.
Resolve when you launch an SD and it ricochets off or passes through your opponent's base and stops away from their base.

Proximity.
Some activated SDs have Proximity effects and need to be launched or be within your Proximity for it to be active or resolve.

—Neal @ CGT

You start your hamlet with just a well. You finish it with numerous beautiful landmarks. Who will be the player whose hamlet will graduate to the finest town?

Hamlet is a fast-playing, grid-less, village builder focusing on resource transport and supply between buildings creating a satisfying feel of engine building and village growth in a package that plays in an hour.

Including solo mode by Dávid Turczi

—description from the designer

Thalassa is a rule of ancient naval warfare. 
It has been published as a bonus game in Vae Victis n°11 and can be played either with miniatures, or with the counters provided in the magazine (6 ships).

Icaion is an Engine Territory Building, Resource Management eurogame for 2 to 4 players designed by Martino Chiacchiera and Marta Ciaccasassi.

In Icaion you become a Seeker, an expert adventurer, sent out by the Organization to hunt for treasures, Qoam, relics and artifacts from ancient times.

Key Features:

 Original illustrations from acclaimed artist Travis Anderson
 More than 70 highly detailed miniatures
 The unique 120mm tall Colossus miniature
 Combine it with Mysthea for a co-op experience "The Fall"
 Deploy your Machines, Harvesters, Scavengers in strategic places of the map before other players to establish control of areas and exploit its resources
 Go on a quest to activate the special Apparatus in the far craters left by the islands of Mysthea




—description from the publisher

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
This is a custom version of the Trivial Pursuit board game made by the the IP oil company.
All questions are related on the Italian national football team.

—user summary

In So ein Mist, each player tries to get as much food for their animal as possible by moving their figure onto the cards with the coveted food. Each round, you may roll up to five dice, one after another, until you are satisfied with the result or roll the same number a second time — then you have to move your figure this number of steps. So ein Mist is a dice-rolling game in which players need to challenge their luck, but if you are too greedy, you can quickly step deep into the dung. The player who has the most points in the end wins.

—description from the publisher

name.value: Crisis: El mundo en juego (Edición de viaje)

item.description:
Times of crisis are running and you have a mission. Show your strategic ability, ambition and win.

Like the classic Risk, we could say that this is a travel edition. With fewer countries and rules in general ... but the goal remains the same: conquest of the world.

Each player's turn consists of:

 gaining reinforcements through number of territories held, control of every territory on each continent, and turning sets of bonus cards.
 Attacking other players using a simple combat rule of comparing the highest dice rolled for each side. Players may attack as often as desired. If one enemy territory is successfully taken, the player is awarded with a bonus card.
 Moving a group of armies to another adjacent territory.




—user summary

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: Génésia is a quick-playing game of placement and civilization, that includes a card-drafting system and a lot of interaction between players.

Equate This! is a game where players create expressions to form an equation using BEDMAS over 5 rounds using number cards and operator cards. The player with the most points at the end of the 5 rounds wins the game. (BEDMAS is outlined in the rules for those who have forgotten it)

The excitement in this game is trying to solve for a common answer, using the cards you have, and get a better equation than all the other players. "Better" is relative though, as you don't need to be a math whiz to win. For example, to solve for 8, you can have 4+4+5-5 or (3-1)2+(15-11). Make them as simple or as complex as you'd like, just make sure you don't get stuck when you need to place down your equation.

—description from the designer

In Nobjects, a die and a card that shows six topics determine what you need to draw for other players to guess, but you're not drawing with pencils, chalk, or other materials. Instead, you draw solely with your fingers on the table, creating a picture with invisible lines that others try to put together in their heads to guess. Whoever recognizes the term will then become the artist for the next round.

4 Builder 1 Wort (4 Pictures 1 Word) is a card game based on the app of the same name, and the gameplay is similar between the two.

In the card game, players are shown four images at once, along with a selection of letters that could belong to a word that relates to all of the images. Can you pick out the right letters to determine what the proper word is? In the co-operative mode, players compete against time to solve as many puzzles as possible before the clock runs out.

"Test your knowledge and have fun with 10,000 questions and answers"
Bound volume contains 912 10 question-long quizzes on topics ranging from science to art and literature to history to film … alternatively, play from 35 pages of 6-question quick quizzes on topics like "Who said?", "World Capitals," "TV Duos," "Our Bodies," etc. There are also quizzes explicitly for younger players. Players keep track of their right answers over multiple rounds; highest scorer wins.

In Bücherwurm, the bookworm is looking for its successor and will test all of you as likely candidates by having you go through a plethora of different categories. In each category, you must find fitting words so that you can match a letter card in your hand. Whoever can get rid of all their letter cards first wins the game and the worthy title of successor!

Bücherwurm: Das Kartenspiel increases the challenge of the original Bücherwurm game because now speed is of the essence, challenging you not only to think along certain lines, but to think quickly. The game includes more categories to provide more variety of play, and it includes a number of play variants.

Choose your warrior! Get your weapons ready! And enter the Holmgang, the deadliest place in the North, where the most powerful warriors fighting each other for life and death. Without fear! Without limits! Are you prepared?

Holmgang is a bluffing combat card game set in Norse history. Players playing as warriors in Norse arena called Holmgang to claim their rights and glory. During the game, players play hidden cards on the board, once all actions are done players reveal cards one by one and execute their actions simultaneously. Move, Attack, Defend or do any of your special character ability to outplay your opponent. But be aware, you are slowly running out of options so be careful in your planning to always have some backup plan.

Each character is equipped with a unique set of weapons and 13 cards. Cards allow players to move with their weapons around the board or do some sneaky moves to try to find an undefended spot where they can hit the enemy with their attack. Attacking is the only way how players can deal damage to an opponent's character and defeat it. Each round players put 4 hidden cards on the board that creates their action decks. Once both action decks are complete, players execute all card from their decks one by one. The games end when one of the player's characters health is reduced to 0.

—description from the publisher

A hybrid of Uno and the word game Ghost. Players start with a hand of 5 cards, mostly letters, and in a turn a player may do one of: 

 Add a letter to the row(s) of cards on the table. Each row of cards is supposed to be a portion of a valid word. 
 Challenge the previous player to name a valid word for each row. 
 Play a specialty card. 
 Draw a card. 




The first player to empty their hand wins.

Specialty cards include: 

 Wild: may be played to a row and stand for any letter.
 Back At You: reverses play order. 
 Invisible: pass for one turn, and a challenge to you from the next player goes to the previous player. 
 New Ghostword: allows a new row of cards to be played to.




—user summary

A unique card game, whose cards mostly have spots like dominoes, and whose play is a bit like Rummy but still unique.

The 54-card deck consists of: 
10 Deuces
12 Treys
12 Fours
10 Fives
 2 Tens
 6 Queens of Spades
 2 Jokers

Players are dealt 4-card hands. In their turn a player: 

 Draws one or more cards from the deck or discard pile. 
 Plays one card from their hand on the table in front of them. 
 Optionally plays one or more Queens on top of other players' cards (one card per Queen), to discard both the cards. The target player may play a Joker to counter the Queen. 
 Discards a card. 




The hand ends once one player has 4 cards on the table in front of them. Each player then scores: 

 The sum of the numbers of the cards in front of them. 
 If they went out, a bonus of 5 points, plus and extra 5 points if their cards are 2-3-4-5, or an extra 10 if they are 4 of a kind. 
 The sum of the cards' values still in hand is subtracted. 




Hands are played until one player reaches at least 100 points, and the highest score wins.

Two decks can be combined for playing up to 8 players.

—user summary

A card game version of Guess Who? Each player spreads out an identical deck of 21 faces in front of them, and draws one card from the Character Cards to show who they are. They then take turns asking each other a yes/no question about the other's drawn face, and then they turn their all cards for whom the answer is "no" face down. The first player to guess the identity of the other player's drawn card wins.

With 2 copies, up to 4 may play together.

—user summary

The object of the game is to make words by adding your cards to columns of letters already on the table. Whenever a word is complete (i.e. it is not possible to add more letters to make a longer word) the player that completed the word removes the cards from the table and keeps them, scoring points. The game ends when a player has put down all their cards. All cards collected from formed words score positive points. All cards left in a player's hand at the end of the game score negative points.

—description from the rulebook

Contents:

 100 Playing Cards
 Game Play Instructions




Playing Time: About 15 minutes

Draw "head" cards and match them with "tail" cards to make words. The first player to build three words with each "tail" card is the winner!

Learn as You Play

 Recognize beginning sounds and word endings
 Decode unfamiliar words
 Build phonics skills




Game includes:

 19 initial sounds
 11 initial blends
 31 word endings




—description from the back the box

Contents:

 100 Playing Cards
 Game Play Instructions




Playing Time: About 15 minutes

Build a word. Use as many letters as possible. Add up the points. Go bananas and build a bunch of words! The first player to reach 30 points wins. Wild Card keeps game play exciting!

Learn as You Play

 Strengthen spelling an reading skills
 Build word recognition and vocabulary
 Develop phonics skills
 Practice addition




—description from the back of the box

Unnützes Quizzen: Pannen & Katastrophen ("Unuseful Knowledge: Glitches & Catastrophes") is a German Trivia Game with obscure facts about different disasters.
—user summary

"Test your useless knowledge!
How many cigars have been on board of the "Titanic"? In how many years our galaxy will collide with the neighboring galaxy Andromeda? And is it really true that in Jamaica a whole beach has been stolen?
For at home, on the go, for in between: 99 quizzes to always have."
—description from the publisher (translated)

"Teste dein unnützes Wissen!
Wie viele Zigarren gab es an Bord der "Titanic"? In wie vielen Jahren wird unsere Galaxie mit der Nachbargalaxie Andromeda kollidieren? Und wurde in Jamaika wirklich mal ein kompletter Strand gestohlen?
Für zu Hause, für unterwegs, für zwischendurch: 99 Quiz-Fragen zum Immerdabeihaben."
—description from the publisher (German)

MOON is a quick game where you'll learn how a real computer works.

To win the game, you must help the astronauts fulfill their mission by solving all the goal cards.

Each goal cards shows a combinations of bits. To solve the goal card, you must store that combination of bits in register A of the CPU. In each round, you can perform as many operations as you wish depending on the energy units available.

There may also be hardware failures that will force you to repair them or look for alternative solutions.

In addition to the solitary or collaborative mode, MOON provides 4 RAM modules to play in competitive mode.

—description from the designer

Each player starts with an empty game card. Players move their pieces around the board, then draw a playing card with a word on it and follow the instructions for the place they land on. The player acts, sings, or mimes to get the other players to guess the word. If the word is guessed correctly, the player fills the appropriate spot on their game card. A player wins when their game card is filled.

—user summary

Theme:
The year is 1560, the year a prophecy claims one ruler will defeat all others and forever hold the throne. Do you have the mastery to build your army, defeat your foes, and prove that you are destined to be the Ultimate Ruler?

Choose your actions wisely as your fate, and that of the throne, is on the line.

---
Play:
All players start with an equal quantity of soldiers. On each turn players draw one Decree card and either play or discard one Decree Card (to draw another). Some cards played modify these actions, allowing additional draws or plays.

Other Decree cards allow players to Bribe, Recruit and cause Battle between their, their opponent, and the Neutral Soldiers. Cards change in power as the game progresses, so make your choices wisely. Strategy Hand-management is key for success in this game.

A great game for on-the-go fun with rapid, card-only play that's easy to learn but hard to master. Strategy evolves as the game progresses and power shifts between you, your enemies, and neutral.

—description from the designer

For What Remains is a skirmish-level wargame set in a post-apocalyptic near future. The game is designed for 2 player competitive play or solitaire play.

There are two ways to play For What Remains: skirmishes and campaigns. Skirmishes are standalone games played for a single victory, with no lasting repercussions. Campaigns are a series of skirmishes linked together to form a larger narrative.

For What Remains is a scenario driven game. Each scenario typically has multiple objectives, and combat between factions is usually secondary. Players win skirmishes by gaining victory points through accomplishing these objectives.

The game board in For What Remains is built from modular tiles which are themed to represent different environments. The default game board is a destroyed urban setting. Players build the game board with nine modular tiles, each of which are divided into a 7x7 grid. Characters use the grids for movement.

Each character in For What Remains is represented by a counter and has a corresponding character card and tokens. During campaign play, characters improve their attributes and develop new abilities as they progress from Recruit to Veteran and then Elite level. A chit pull system is used for unit activation, and a step-loss system is used for tracking injuries during skirmishes.

Players control characters from one of the game’s six factions. The Combine and Freemen Coalition are part of the core game; the other four factions can be integrated seamlessly.

Freemen Coalition: The Freemen Coalition is a loose-knit band of human rebels who specialize in guerrilla warfare.

Combine: The Combine is the military arm of the government that rules over much of what is left of the world.

Echo: Echo is a faction led by a secretive cabal of humans with psychic powers.

Erthen: Erthen are a biologically developed race formed from a mixture of human, mineral, and organic matter.

Order of the New Dawn: The Order of the New Dawn are creatures from the strange subterranean realm known as the Basement.

Soldiers of Light: The Soldiers of Light are humans who believe the fall of mankind was brought about due to a dependence on technology.

—description from the designer

Dead Reckoning is a game of exploration, piracy and influence based in a Caribbean-eque setting. Each player commands a ship and crew and seeks to amass the greatest fortune. They will do this through pirating, trading, treasure hunting, and importantly, capturing and maintaining control over the uninhabited but resource rich islands of the region.

- Customize your ship: Your ship is represented by a token on the board. The board starts mostly unexplored and will be revealed as you venture into uncharted waters. You also have a ship board where you will load cargo and treasure, and can customize the guns, speed or holding space of your ship.

- Card-Craft your crew: You have a small deck of cards which will drive your actions in the game, with each card representing one of your crew members. This deck works like a deck-building game, however, cards in the deck are sleeved, and rather than add new crew cards to your deck, you will improve the skill and abilities of your crew cards in your deck by adding transparent “advancement” cards into the sleeves. In addition to transparent advancements, crew will also “level-up” naturally during the game using a new card-leveling mechanic not used in other card crafting games from AEG like, Mystic Vale, or Edge of Darkness.

- Control the region: The region is filled with many deserted islands. These islands are a major source of treasure, and players will be battling for control of these islands.

- Battle via a dynamic cube-tower: You can battle other players’ ships or NPC merchant ships, and these battles are resolved via a totally new take on what a cube tower can be, with crew cards and ship powers increasing your chances of victory.

- Uncover secrets of the sea: Expansions for Dead Reckoning use a “Saga” system whereby certain content remains hidden and is only discovered and added to the game organically via playing. Rather than add everything at once, you gradually add it by playing and discovering. Depending on luck and player choice, less or more new content may get added each game.

—description from the publisher

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
The players represent mice that want to eat the largest quantity of food. Food cards are revealed one by one, and, after each food card, players simultaneously chose if they want to stop or continue. If two identical food cards are revealed, me mice that are still exploring lose all the points for the food.
The winner is who reaches 25 points at the end of the round.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description: This game includes four variants, ranging from a rock-paper-scissors game using cards to a classic memory game. At the end of each game, a "hugs die" is thrown, and the winner gives a type of hug according to the die result.

You have been chosen to participate in a car race on a hidden, magical island. The island has transformed you into a specific character with unique powers and abilities; You must use them to help you win the race.

The object of the game is to be the first player across the finish line.

There are three levels of play: 
Beginner - Playing as yourself (without a character)
Intermediate (Basic Game) - Playing with a character
Advanced - Playing with a team of characters

In a Basic Game, each player begins with a Guardian Card, a Dashboard a Turbo Card and a Character. The Guardian Card is a log of the training that you have received from the guardians of the island. The Dashboard contains a Health Meter which indicates the health of your character, a Damage Meter which indicates the condition of your vehicle and a Binoculars Meter which helps you look into the distance. The Turbo Card allows the player to take a Turbo Roll when rolling a 6. During the Turbo Roll the player is completely defenseless.

During a player's turn, they can play any of their character powers and abilities. A player then rolls the High Speed Die to move their vehicle down the road (during certain times they must roll the Low Speed Die). They collect Game Cards and Coins along the way. They must traverse difficult terrain and battle hostile animals and other players.

Each character has at least three unique powers and/or abilities. A "power" requires a player to spend tokens and are limited. An "ability" is constant throughout the entire game.

There are different areas of the board that present unique challenges, such as the quicksand, Gator Lake, Wildebeest Canyon, Rickety Bridge, Andy Straightaway-Ice Road, and finding their way out of Tarancon Volcano.

There are friendly animals which help you such as Jora-The Lion which provides you with strength which is used in battling, the cheetah which provides you with speed, the meercats which energize your binoculars and others which provide you with coins to buy items at the Trading Post.
 There are four hidden paths. The player who possesses the compass is able to find and go through these paths. Other players may steal the compass.

During certain conditions, Game Cards can be flipped. If so, the player cannot use them. To un-flip them, the player must roll a 4 and choose not to move their vehicle.

The game ends when the first player crosses the finish line. The next closest player is declared 2nd Place and so on.

There is also tournament format. A tournament is when 2 to 5 players have agreed to participate in 10 races. During tournament play, points are awarded for pole position and guardian training. The winner of the tournament is the player with the most points.

-description from designer

The 2012 edition is a compilation of the base game and Samarkand: Routes to Riches â€“ Family Connection which was released by itself at Essen 2010 and through the BGG Store.

As members of merchant families in Samarkand: Routes to Riches, the players marry into other wealthy merchant families. They expand the trading routes of these families and establish trade relationships with other families. The player who gains the most victory points with relationships and goods will be the winner at the end of the game.

Each turn, the players either marry into a merchant family or expand the trading route of a family they are already married into.

To marry into a family, the player pays the cost of the family. Only two players may marry into each family. To expand the trading route of a family, the player must be married into the family and may pay for the route with the money of the family. The goal is to meet other families not met before (gaining trade relationship markers) and to reach goods spaces first (gaining goods tokens).

When all families have established at least one trade relationship or one family has established five trade relationships, the game ends. Each player scores their goods cards with the corresponding goods markers they have acquired, the trade relationship markers they have collected, and their money.

Family expansion:
Family ties are established even tighter now. Being merchants, the players equip their sons and daughters with goods and gems and send them out to travel the trading routes. The only thing still missing is the adequate partner. Which marriage is most promising?

link.value: Samarkand: Routes to Riches – Family Connection

item.description:
“What you leave behind is not what is engraved in stone monuments, but what is woven into the lives of others.”
Pericles (circa 495-429 BCE)

Live an Epic, Odyssey adventure; as one of Ancient Greece’s greatest thinkers in this new Sandbox, Tabletop experience. Forge your destiny in an age of city states and ancient wisdom. In Philosophia, you will build schools, battle it out in public debates, learn profound wisdom and make deals with the Olympic Gods. All in an attempt to prove yourself the greatest mind of the era.

The goal in Philosophia is to gain three Labyrinth Tokens before the ancient Greek World is superseded by the Romans. There are many different paths you can take to do this; from building schools dedicated to your teachings, to locking yourself away in temples to develop your ideas. All players who gain 3 Labyrinth tokens will finish the game with a tense final public debate; exchanging Sophistry and Syllogistic arguments until one thinker is crowned the greatest. Good luck!

Philosophia, has been carefully designed to be a replay-able game with premium components. Visit philosophiagame.com to learn more.

Game Play.

Philosophia is a turn based game, on your turn you will move and then take one action, limiting downtime, with no upkeep phases. Being a sandbox experience there are many things you can do:
 
 You can build a following in your current region of ancient Greece (9 of these unlocks a Labyrinth Token). 
 You can hire builders and build schools dedicated to your teachings (4 schools unlock a Labyrinth Token)
 You can research your ideas in Greek temples to unlock ancient wisdom cards (3 of these unlock a Labyrinth Token).
 You can visit Oracles to gain special unique powers using a card drafting mechanic.
 You can gain the favour of Athena goddess of wisdom by winning a blind auction. 


And much more, the game features 13 actions and over 30 unique paths to victory!

The game will end in a tense final debate utilising a unique twist on the Rock, paper, scissors, lizard, Spock mechanic. Where you will use the Syllogism and Sophistry cards you have gained throughout the game to find out who is the greatest mind of the era!

—description from the designer

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name.value: Coal & Guns!: Tactical level naval rules for the pre-dreadnought era

item.description:
Coal & Guns! is a set of fast-play naval rules for the pre-dreadnaught era aiming to emphasize manoeuvre over detailed gunnery and damage tracking. Intended for squadrons of up to about half a dozen ships per side.

—user summary

A simple racegame with Canoes.You throw the dice and move as many steps as the dice shows. Sometimes you end your move at a spot where you either are lucky or poor.
In the beginning of the game you also have the opportunity to bet on whose canoe is going to win.

Many animals are crisscrossing the Australian outback. To control where they're going in Outback Crossing, players lay down tiles one at a time onto a 5 x 5 grid (6 x 6 for five and six players), claim ownership of different "trails", and change things around with the action tiles. At the end of the game, single tiles won't score — except for the Tasmanian Devil — and the more tiles of one kind you have on a trail, the better the score; one per species on a trail also score very well. The Tasmanian Devil has a special value and scores even higher.

—description from the publisher

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Story of the Game:

In the year 1295 (the year ending March 20, 1917), that is to say, 95 years after the time when Tehran was determined as capital of Iran, the small bazaar (market place) of Tehran which had not so much flourish before facing an increase in number of immigrants. Bazaar of Tehran was gradually becoming a big market place which needed a capable manager. For this reason a competition was held between 5 experienced businessmen of that time in order to decide who will become the “Elder” one of the bazaar.

Aim of the Game: By the end of the 5th day, the player with the highest total of gold coins wins the game.

How to play:

Stage 1: Taking the Tile of Goods
This stage has 2 parts. In the first part: each player randomly takes tiles from the bag keep some of them to expose to other pkayer and return the rest to the bag.

Stage 2: Transaction 
Any transaction is possible and free in this stage.
In this stage the players are permitted to transact and exchange any goods with the asset coins( gold coins ) or with other goods in only 2 minutes which should be controlled by a timer.

Stage 3: Costing and Sale (bidding)
In this stage ( considering the main board-game ) all the goods will be sold.each player holds one of the costing coins in his fists ( considering limitation of costing for each goods ) and keep his hand in front of the shop and all the players open their fists simultaneously. the person who has offered lower price takes action for selling his goods.

Stage 4: Storing
In this stage all the goods that have not been sold and remained in the shops will be flipped to the other side ( Black and white side) and will soon be expired. It means that , if they are not sold the next day,they will be removed feom the shop without receiving any amount of money and will be returned to the bag.

Stage 5: Movement of the day tracker token

End of the Game: 
The game will be finished on the 5th day after the end of the sale.

—description from the designer

name.value: ちいさいことはいいことだ (Small Number)

item.description:
Arc of Eckaris is a strategy board game for 4 to 6 players set in an original sci-fi universe.

During the game, you will use the influence of one of six unique factions to acquire planets, defeat your opponents, and/or capture the Arc of Eckaris.

Players take turns choosing from limited of number of actions to perform per turn including playing cards, using unique player powers, and deploying Influence, among others.

Players may win the game in one of three ways: Acquire 20 Victory Points, defeat all other players by depleting their Influence, or acquire the Arc of Eckaris.

—description from the publisher

Yet another clone of Monopoly but with 144 cases, 24 series and many mechanics to influence your movement. Consequently, the game becomes a lot more strategic.

Main features:
All series are distributed at the beginning among the players
Players can use special cards to advance faster or slower, foward or backward.
Special cases or cards also allow players to move around the board strategically.

—description from the designer

In Multiverse War you are a Viceroy, chosen to lead one of the first expeditions trough the Stone Portal to colonize the new worlds. Explore the wilderness, push the Empire’s border by constructing new Fortresses. Hire mighty heroes, train powerful armies and defeat all enemies, old and new. Show that you are worthy of your Emperor’s trust, may he live forever.

Multiverse War is a blend of 4X, MOBA like heroes, area control block wargame. Key elements are RPG style character progression for heroes, armies gain battle experience and become stronger, unique heroes and different faction, modular map and random encounters. All these factors give high replayability.

A turn has 3 phases.
Revenue phase: Collect revenue from your starting settlement and expansions.
Build phase: Construct buildings or tile improvements, recruit armies or a hero
Action phase: Move all available units you wish to this turn

Win the game through conquest (conquering the opponent's starting settlement), domination (construct all 4 Fortresses), by constructing a new Stone Portal (by controlling stone mines on the map), trough magic (by reaching level 6 with your hero) or through might (reaching the highest rank with your 3 military units).

—description from the designer

name.value: Dominate Grail War: Fate/Stay night on Board Game
Domineito Gureiru Uō ~Feito/Sutei Naito On Bōdo Gēmu~
ドミネイトグレイルウォー ~フェイト/ステイナイト オン ボードゲーム~

item.description: A roll-and-move game along a 100-space track depicting the various expeditions that discovered and settled Australia, from De Quiros and Torres in 1605, Tasman (1642), Dirk Hartog (1616), Dampier (1688 & 1699), Cook (1770), Phillp (1788), Bass (1798), Grant (1800) and Flinders 1802-03. Brief historical notes are given, and various spaces give penalties and bonuses.
A promotionele game for the town of Gorinchem. It’s a retheme of The Game of Goose.

The game uses laces and an unusual textile board made of felt which can be rolled up and worn in a pocket, making it a perfect travel game. Although it may look like a simple children’s game with all those flowers and cute meadow animals, it offers a tense and thinky experience for two to four players of all ages.

The board represents a meadow full of flowers. The flowers have a hole in the center in order to thread the lace through them. Players alternate in threading with their lace and try to collect flowers with as many leaves as possible. They can collect any unoccupied flower on the board but the farther it is, the more lace it requires and they play only as long as the length of the lace allows them.

The rules can be explained within a minute, but the game offers quite a lot of strategic depth and thanks to more than thirty animal cards also a huge replayability. At the start of the game, players agree on the amount of animals they want to use, setting up the complexity of the game. Each animal gets it’s favorite color and adds a special rule to all flowers of that color.

Control monsters to steal candies!

In Kingdom's Candy: Monsters, you are a villain eager to accumulate candies. You use monsters as servants to help you in your mission, but if you don't feed your monsters, they will eat your candies and run away! Use sugar cubes to cast spells and activate monster abilities.

—description from the designer

A fast-paced, competitive, block stacking game. You have a minute to build as many structure cards as possible.

All cards have a different difficulty level, and that level is also the number of points you receive from completing the card. (i.e Level 4 difficulty gives you 4 points).

You can choose to discard difficult cards (at the cost of points) and get to easier ones, or risk spending time for it all to come tumbling down when you place the last block!

The game time and player count is infinity scaleable and only limited by the number of cards in the deck!

—description from the designer

Birdtrails is a pair of educational race games featuring 140 different kinds of North American birds.

In Game 1, placers roll and spin to make it back to the trailhead with the most impressive collection of birds seen. Special points are awarded for taking time to improve the birds' habitat!

In Game 2, players do not use the spinner, and can only collect birds if they are able to correctly identify them, based on a photo. Random events are reduced, making it more a game of skill and knowledge.

The game comes with 300 beautiful cards, featuring nature photography by Bob Ball. A handful of scoring variants are also included.

Endorsed by the Greater Ozarks Audubon Society.

A cross between Scrabble and Memory/Concentration/Pelmanism. 
—user summary

Quatro is a word game for 2, 3 or 4 players. Words are formed by remembering the position of letter coins placed face down on the playing board. Players compete for the highest score by making words of at least four letters. Keen memory and ingenuity are rewarded by bonus points for Premium and Dividend words.

OBJECTIVE

The objective is to turn up coins all of which together form a word of four or more letters. Scoring is based on the value of the letters in the word. In addition, bonuses are scored for Premium words, which are words containing five or more letters, and also for Dividend words, which are words made entirely of letters all of the same color (all gold or all black).

Charts, showing the frequency of the letters and the point value assigned to each letter, are printed on the playing board.

—description from the rulebook

This early product of Zoo-phonics uses different decks with sets of pairs of cards. One deck has 26 pairs for each letter of the alphabet, along with the name of the animal assigned to that letter, e.g. Allie Alligator, Honey Horse, Vincent Vampire Bat. Another deck has 40 pairs of 2- or 3-letter blends and digraphs.

The three games are adaptations of traditional childrens' games: Zoophonia (Old Maid, except the one with the Zoophonia card wins); Zoo-Fish (Go Fish), and Zoo-Memory (Memory). The alphabet deck also says it can be used for spelling games. Whenever cards are requested or matches made, the player must say the card's animal name, make its sound, and do its sign according to the Zoo-phonics kinesthetic system.

—user summary

Finger Guns at High Noon is a fast-paced game of strategy, negotiation, and pure hilarity—battle royale style. 
 Craft your plan, convince the crowd to join in, then count down and draw your finger guns. Hand gestures show everyone’s actions and targets. Eliminate players with pistols, dynamite, and power shots, or stand to the side and lasso up an ally. Last player standing is the winner—unless the ghosts eliminate everyone.
 Do you have the fastest draw in the west? Time to put your moxie to the test in Finger Guns at High Noon!

—description from the publisher

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
There are only two time-travel devices in existence, and you and your friend have managed to steal them. They will allow you to be the perfect thieves, traveling through time to when your target is most vulnerable and snatching it away to the future ... er, present.

It wouldn't have been possible without your friend, but now that you have the time-travel device, you don't need him. So you have decided to go back to the night the time-travel devices were invented and steal them BOTH. Unfortunately, your backstabbing buddy had the same idea.

GOAL

You need to infiltrate the facility with the time-travel devices while the cameras are off, the alarm is disabled, and the robot guard is deactivated. If neither player successfully infiltrates, or both players infiltrate at the same time, shuffle the decks and start a new game. After all, you can both travel through time, so you might as well try again.

—description from the box and the rulebook

Castlecomb is a card laying game of territory control for 1-5 players. As you play cards of terrain, settlements, and strongholds to create territories of your own, watch out as other players are looking to do the same. The cards a have requirements that have to be met to be played and to be operational to score at the end of the game, where the high score is the victor.

—description form the designer

"A unique card game of Spelling and Poker."

The Deck: The cards have traditional playing cards suit and rank in one corner (e.g. two of clubs, queen of hearts), and a letter of the alphabet in the opposite corner. There are also 2 jokers.

Play: For a hand, each player is dealt 7 cards, and looks for both the best poker hand, and the longest word, they have in their hand. Then each player holds out a fist with 0-2 tokens in it, and all open their hands at the same time. 0 tokens means they are trying for the best poker hand, 1 token for the longest word, 2 tokens for both (Double Down).

Scoring: For those trying for just the best poker hand, or just the longest word, the player who has the best hand gets 1 point, with tied players each getting 1 point. A player going Double Down must have the best hand in both areas, with no ties. If they do, they get 4 points, if not, they lose 2 points.

More hands are played until one player has 12 points in a 2-player game, 10 points for 3 or 4, 8 points for 5 or 6, 6 points for 7 or 8.

—user summary

This deck has two copies of each letter of the alphabet, with the letters painted by Donna Kern in delightful and creative ways. For example, the 'A' is an A-shaped apple with a bit out of it; the 'K' is made from keys, the 'R' from a ribbon, etc.

Rules are included for several games: Kern Rummy (draw and discard until you can use all your hand to make one or more words); children's games Go Fish, Rotten Egg (Old Maid) and Concentration; and KernWords (laying down cards in crossword fashion, with new cards not having to make words in every direction).

—user summary

Adrift: Lost at Sea is a challenging, 2 - 4 player, cooperative card game that focuses on bringing people together. It’s like the Oregon Trail meets a 16th Century shipwreck - As you make the journey back home on the unforgiving tides, your table becomes the lifeboat and you become the survivors. Plus, at the end of the game, you'll get a unique sea shanty about your voyage to sing (or chant) together and reminisce about your adventure!

On this journey home, you'll endure storms, navigate the seas, balance and repair your tiny lifeboat, fish for sustenance, and work together to help each other survive!

Players try to complete all cards in the route home deck while outlasting storms and maladies to win the game.

—description from the publisher

The Pla-Pak deck has two cards for each letter, showing a few items that start with that letter, and two "Dunce" cards, showing a boy on a stool wearing a traditional Dunce cap.

Rules for 4 games are included:


 Rummy-Dunce: 2-4 players each get 10 cards. Typical draw-and-discard play is done until one player can use his hand to spell one or more words; they score 10 points plus 1 point per each letter in others' hands that are not used in words they spell from their hands. Dunce cards are wild and stand for any letter. The first to 50 points wins. 



 Grand Champion: Like Rummy-Dunce, except the discard pile is spread out to see each card. One can take any card in the discard pile along with every card above it as long as they immediately lay down a word using that letter; only one card is discarded. When the deck is used up players use as many of their cards as they can to form words, and get one point per unused card. Each player is eliminated on reaching 50 total points, and the last player left is Grand Champion. 



 Hit the Bowl: A player sits in a chair and throws each card one at a time at a bowl 6 feet away. After the deck is all used the player gets 1 point for each card in the bowl, and spells as many words as they can from those cards, scoring the length of each word. First player to 50 wins. 



 Dunce: Played like Old Maid, using just one of the Dunce cards. 


—user summary

Combilet is a combination letter game consisting of 76 cards. Each card has four selections of single and two letter combinations. The red side is made up of consonant-vowel, and vowel-consonant combinations, such as SA-AS, and the black side is made up of either two single letters, or a single letter and a double consonant, such as PR, TH etc., with some exceptions.

"The selections on each card are listed on the upper left hand corner. [Note there are four upper-left corners depending on how you orient the card, each one having a different selection in large font.]
—description from the rulebook

There are rules for 3 games:

Combilet

Each player has a 5-card hand. On their turn a player may do one of these:

 Play a word of 5+ letters from the hand in front them. 
 Play a word of 3 or 4 letters from the hand to a common pool. 
 Take a word from the pool by adding cards that make it a 5+ letter word. 
 Take a word from another player by using cards that increase it, change it, or replace single letters with 2-letter combinations. 




Then they fill their hand back out to 5 cards. Play presumably goes until the deck runs out or some other end condition is reached.

Each word's score encourages using 2-letter combinations: its score is 5 points each for the first two combinations, 10 points each for each combination beyond two, and 1 point for each single-letter card in the word.

Fast Combilet

Each player gets 5 cards which they try to make one or more words out of. Scoring is similar to that in regular Combilet. The player with the highest-scoring hand gets his score and that of each other play.

Solitaire

The deck is split into 5 piles, and the player makes words from the top cards, laying them aside and trying to finish the whole deck.

—user summary

NAPOLEON RETURNS 1815 is our first game using our action point/battle card system. We've combined several ideas into one fast playing game of Napoleon's 1815 Waterloo Campaign.

With fewer than 20 pieces on the board, strategic movement based on action point allocation, a unique twist on a classic battle card system, the game plays in under 90 minutes. The game is playable by 2 to 3 players and several games can be played in an evening. Great for Tournament play!
 Each side receives a set number of action points to move pieces and battle. Each piece on the board is a corps in the French, Anglo-Allied, and Prussian armies, so each side has 4 - 8 pieces on board. As your pieces move they will gain fatigue, and as they battle they gain fatigue and casualties.

The battle system is card play, matching the cards played based on the type of units in the corps (infantry, cavalry, or artillery). Victory is determined by the capture of terrain and eliminating enemy units.

-description from publisher

From a deck of 48 letter cards, the dealer chooses the size of the hand for the deal, dealing 3, 4 or 5 cards to each player face down. At a signal from the dealer, everyone looks at their hand and tries to make a word using all their cards. They can discard cards and be dealt replacements as desired. The first person to make a word says "Word!" and gets 10 points; achieving 100 points total over several hands wins the game.

An alternate way to play is to deal 8 cards per player. Players take turns placing one letter in the center of the table; if a player completes a word using all letters they take them and start a new "trick". Taking the most words wins.

—user summary

This game dates back to the Persians, who played a crude version in which the board was thirteen feet across. The counter was made of stone and took forty slaves to lift; as a result, play was slow. Modern gamers have speeded play, but have not modified the basic futility of the system.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Ultracombat: Normandy is an easy, fast-paced set of squad-level skirmish wargames rules for depicting the frenetic close-ranged combat that occurred during the Normandy Campaign of WW2. The system puts players in command of up to a platoon of infantry supported with tanks, AT guns and devastating heavy weapons.

Key Features:

 Forces are built in elements, so players can play the real tactics of the day like scouting, suppressive fire, and fire and movement.
 Command is an integral part of the game.
 Real ranges of weapons are used so measuring on the battlefield is kept to a minimum.
 A unique card-based system gives players tactical options in play.




—description from the publisher

Hemlock is a strategic, medieval themed, card game.

In it, your goal is to manipulate an unfolding conspiracy to your advantage. Populate your King's court with high-valued figures, reduce the likelihood of their deaths, and minimize your opponents’ ability to do the same.

Hemlock features a play deck of 66 cards (11 cards per suit). Each card has a static or variable point value as well as an associated ability. When a player plays a card from their hand, they choose to play it for either points or for ability.

Hemlock is played over a series of rounds. At the beginning of each round, 2 cards are dealt face down to the center of the play area. These are the conspiracy cards. Actions played during the course of a round can change the conspiracy cards, but there are always, and only, 2 conspiracy cards in a given round.

Players take turns moving clockwise, playing 1 card per turn from their hand with the goal of accruing the highest round-point total. The player with most points at the end of a round earns the privilege of examining the 2 conspiracy cards and then assigning them to 2 different players' courts (score piles).

The number of cards in each player's court is known to all, but the value of the cards are kept secret even to their owner until a specified number of cards is present in a given court. When this number of cards is reached, the game ends. Players tally the value of the cards in their court (the ones that aren't poisoned by Hemlock!) and the player with the highest valued court wins.

—description from the publisher

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
