Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
It seems like just a jumbled grid of letters, but as you cover letters on the board, words begin to come into focus. But before you know it, the board tightens and suddenly words become harder and harder to spot...and you're running out of time!

In Blind Spot, players place "spots" to cover letters and race the clock to reveal words. The game becomes more difficult as more spots are placed on the board, and players have to quickly and cleverly use their spots not only to find words, but also to block their opponents to be the last player standing!

Blind Spot is an innovative word game with endless replayability, including rules for team and solo play! In this word game, it's what you don't see that you will help you win!

Something's rotten in the realm of Labamba...

The annual rave party is an event where every self-respecting wizard and sorceress has to make an appearance; however, this year's party was so epic, that in the morning the guests – all tired and hungover – discovered that someone has murdered the Archmage!
No one knows how, no one knows when. It's quite possible that even the murderer him or herself is not aware of what happened last night, since barely anyone remembers anything. Unfortunately, according to the ancient laws of Labamba, the one that kills the Archmage may become a powerful Darchmage, bringing Darkness onto the land. And if there is one thing that Darkness hates, it's fun, techno, lasers and glitter – which is all that is dear to the magical folk.
Thus, it's time to pull yourselves together, put your holo detective hats on your aching heads and catch the killer, before he grows too powerful!

RAVEHARD: Magiczna Gra Karciana is a party game that mixes elements of classic card battle games, games of deduction and deception, as well as more cooperative titles. It's meant to be played by 3-5 players aged 12 and more.

Over the course of the game, which lasts three rounds, the players will have to work together in order to discover who killed the Archmage during the magical rave party yesternight. To achieve this goal, they'll have to overcome dangerous obstacles, including boss fights (each boss capable of summoning powerful minions) and unpredictable events. After each round the players gain a new clue which sheds some light on the last night's incident and points towards a possible murder weapon.
If the players manage to survive all three rounds, they reach the Archmage's Chamber. There they may incapacitate one of them, should they be certain that he's the killer. If they are correct – they win the game; if they are wrong – the murderer steps out of the shadows and attacks the rest of the players. The side that emerges victorious from this final confrontation wins the game.

Do not trust anyone – not even yourself! Each player starts the game with two different objects which may turn out to be the murder weapons – or they may prove your innocence. During your turn you may switch the objects with those belonging to other players in order to frame them and clear your name. However, not until the very end will it be possible to tell which object is really the murder weapon. Thus, during the game you'll have to bluff, form alliances, deceive and distract, both openly – and secretly, using the Flirt Cards that let you pass private messages, scheme and conspire (and flirt).

This game is for you if you enjoy playing such titles as Magic: The Gathering, Munchkin, Hero Realms, Epic Spell Wars of the Battle Wizards, Love Letter, Mascarade, Coup, Not Alone, PENNY DREADFUN: Duchy, Demony, Dickensy.

—description from the publisher

Å¹le siÄ™ dzieje w magicznym Å›wiecie Labamba…

Doroczna techno-impreza, na której musi pojawiÄ‡ siÄ™ kaÅ¼dy
szanujÄ…cy siÄ™ mag i czarodziejka, byÅ‚a tak epicka, Å¼e o poranku
skacowani i zmÄ™czeni goÅ›cie odkryli, Å¼e ktoÅ› zamordowaÅ‚
Arcymaga!
Nie wiadomo jak, nie wiadomo kiedy. Prawdopodobnie nawet sam
morderca nie wie, co zrobiÅ‚, bo maÅ‚o kto pamiÄ™ta wydarzenia
wspomnianej nocy. Niestety, wedÅ‚ug odwiecznych praw Labamby,
zabójca Arcymaga moÅ¼e staÄ‡ siÄ™ potÄ™Å¼nym Darkcymagiem,
sprowadzajÄ…c tym samym CiemnoÅ›Ä‡ na caÅ‚Ä… krainÄ™! A jeÅ›li jest coÅ›, czego CiemnoÅ›Ä‡ nienawidzi, to dobra zabawa, techno, lasery i brokat – wszystko to, co jest bliskie czarodziejskiemu Å›wiatu.
Pora zatem wziÄ…Ä‡ siÄ™ w garÅ›Ä‡, przywdziaÄ‡ na obolaÅ‚e gÅ‚owy odblaskowe czapeczki detektywów, rozwiÄ…zaÄ‡ zagadkÄ™ Å›mierci Arcymaga i zÅ‚apaÄ‡ mordercÄ™, nim ten uroÅ›nie w siÅ‚Ä™.

Ravehard: Magiczna Gra Karciana to gra dla 3-5 graczy w wieku 12+ Å‚Ä…czÄ…ca elementy klasycznej gry karcianej, gry blefu i dedukcji oraz gry kooperacyjnej.

W czasie rozgrywki, trwajÄ…cej trzy rundy, gracze bÄ™dÄ… wspóÅ‚pracowaÄ‡, aby pokonaÄ‡ wiele niebezpieczeÅ„stw: bossów i ich popleczników oraz przetrwaÄ‡ nieprzewidziane zdarzenia. Po kaÅ¼dej rundzie gracze zdobywajÄ… dowody, które pozwolÄ… im ustaliÄ‡ jakie byÅ‚o narzÄ™dzie zbrodni oraz co naprawdÄ™ siÄ™ wydarzyÅ‚o.
JeÅ¼eli uda im siÄ™ przetrwaÄ‡ trzy rundy, gracze dotrÄ… do komnaty Arcymaga. JeÅ¼eli sÄ… pewni, kto spoÅ›ród nich jest mordercÄ…, mogÄ… go wytypowaÄ‡ i obezwÅ‚adniÄ‡ – wtedy gracze wygrywajÄ…. JeÅ¼eli nie – morderca ujawni siÄ™ i zapoluje na graczy: druÅ¼yna, która wygra ostateczne starcie, wygrywa grÄ™.

Nie ufaj nikomu, nawet sobie! KaÅ¼dy z graczy rozpoczyna grÄ™ z pewnymi przedmiotami, które Å›wiadczyÄ‡ mogÄ… o ich winie lub stanowiÄ‡ alibi. W czasie swojej tury gracze mogÄ… podrzucaÄ‡ innym te przedmioty, próbujÄ…c zwaliÄ‡ winÄ™ na nich i oczyÅ›ciÄ‡ siÄ™ z zarzutów. Jednak do samego koÅ„ca nie bÄ™dzie wiadomo, który przedmiot naprawdÄ™ okaÅ¼e siÄ™ narzÄ™dziem zbrodni. Przez caÅ‚Ä… rozgrywkÄ™ gracze bÄ™dÄ… blefowaÄ‡, zwieraÄ‡ sojusze, oszukiwaÄ‡
siÄ™ nawzajem i mÄ…ciÄ‡ – jawnie oraz niejawnie – przy wykorzystaniu specjalnych kart Flirtu, sÅ‚uÅ¼Ä…cych do przekazywania sobie informacji i knucia.

—description from the publisher (Polish)

You play a game studio and need to build your team and develop the best game. You play Team Member, Studio Event and Publish Event cards to fulfill Game Concept cards. Each Game Concept Card needs a certain number of Skill Points in different areas (Design, Build, Test, Publish) to fulfilled and is worth 1-3 Stars. The first player to gain 8 Stars wins the game.

Monaco has two identical decks of 54 cards. 52 of them have:

 Traditional playing card ranks and suits in the upper left corner (e.g. King of Spades)
 A one- or two-letter prefix in the upper left corner (copied in small print above the card's rank). 
 Four suffixes of 1-4 letters listed below the card's suit along the left side. Each suffix is printed in either black, red, green or brown ink; the mix and order of the colors varies from card to card, so the color is probably significant but the pattern is hard to discern. 




The remaining 2 cards contain a list of 300 words, each of which is a combination of a prefix and a suffix from the other cards. These words actually look mostly like nonsense words and are likely a set of names, perhaps associated with Monaco.

It looks apparent that an important part of the game is to combine cards so that a prefix and a suffix combine to make a word in the list. But the game's mechanics, the meaning of the different colors, and even its publication details are unknown until a copy of their rules can be found.

—user summary

The game's contents consist of 104 cards -- each of which shows the rank and suit of five traditional cards -- and 4 jokers. The five cards thus comprise a poker hand, and every type of poker hand is included: royal flush, straight flush, four of a kind, full house, flush, straight, three of a kind, two pairs, one pair, high single card.

—user summary

RULES FOR TEXAS POKER

To play this game, remember each card has a five-card Poker hand, for a total of 104 different Poker hands in two decks of cards. It is like playing with 520 regular playing cards.

For fast Texas Poker, play with one card to each player where the best five-card poker hand wins. You may exchange that one card for another if you wish to. High hand wins.

Now, try playing with two Texas Poker Cards to each player, making the best five-card Poker hand from the now ten different numbers and suits each player has. You may also exchange or draw one more card, turning in to the dealer your discard. Try playing 6-7-8-9 or even 10 Poker with just two cards.

You may play this together with an ordinary deck of cards. To play the game this way, deal out one card from the Texas Poker Deck to each player. Each player may then receive up to three cards from the regular deck of cards. Have Fun!!! Plus, make your own rules.

NO SHOOTING, PLEASE ...

—description from the back of the box

Object of the game is to remove all the bolts from Frankenstein's foot one by one using the included "mad scientist wrench" tool. One wrong move and the foot comes "alive". There are several difficulty levels the game can be set to. The players are eliminated if they cause the foot to move - the last player standing is the winner.

—user summary

The LINGO deck consists of 54 playing cards. Each contains a letter and a number 1-11.

Each player is dealt 3 cards, and in a turn a player either plays 1-3 cards to the table to form a word, or draws 1 card and discards 1 card.

The cards in the center form a 5x5 array. With the first word played, one of the cards is designated as the center of the square. After the first word, each word must use all the cards played and at least one card already on the table. Consecutive letters in a word must be adjacent in any direction, orthogonal or diagonal, but the word as a whole may zigzag and change directions. It's like the array from Big Boggle, built up gradually with cards rather than dice.

Each word scores like this: letters already on the board score their printed value, letters played from the hand are double their value, unless they are played to a corner of the square, or are the last cards played in the square, in which case their value is tripled.

Their is also a solitaire game: one plays cards in a row, one at a time, and when a set of consecutive cards make a word, they are made into a single pile with any of those letters on the top. If all the cards can be combined into a single pile at the end, one wins.

—user summmary

name.value: Race to Planet X: Number Bond Game

item.description:
Race to Planet X: Number Bond Game is a board game that has fun game mechanics and helps K-3rd graders master number bonds, addition, and subtraction. Families can play a quick game in 15 minutes, and score some major parenting points for non-screen family time that also doubles as math practice for the kids.

The Game: 

 Take turns making Power Combos (3 cards that make a number bond) to move forward on the game board. 
 Make Power Combos before another player ZAPs a card from your hand. SCORE your Power Combos before another player SMASH one and make you move backwards. 
 First to reach Planet X wins!




—description from the publisher

In Nuts And Bots, 2-4 players compete to construct their giant robot, a MegaBot, by building it part by part. First player to build their MegaBot wins.

The board is the Factory and consists of shared Workstation Tiles that players move around the Factory to form Assembly Lines. Blueprints show the pattern of Workstations required in an Assembly Line to build legs, torsos, arms, and heads, and all of these are needed to complete a MegaBot.

Players have a number of WorkBots and can build more. WorkBots are the driving force in the Factory and each Workstation needs a WorkBot on it. Only then will the Workstation be a functioning part of an Assembly Line. Only by moving Workstations around the Factory to match a Blueprint and placing a WorkBot on each Workstation will the next part of a MegaBot come rolling off the Assembly Line.

On their turn, players can move a Workstation and move a WorkBot. Each type of Workstation is limited in number, and players will try to move Workstations out of other players’ Assembly Lines to use within their own. Take control of a Workstation by having more WorkBots on it than anyone else, then it can be moved. Protect a Workstation by having enough WorkBots left on it to prevent the other players moving it.

Nuts And Bots has simple rules and simple actions but requires thought and puzzle-solving to win in an ever-changing environment.

—description from the publisher

In X Arrr!, 2-4 pirate crews journey around an island full of secret paths to collect their buried treasure. X marks the spot! The first player to get both pirates and all of their treasure back to their ship is the winner. Arrr!

The island is built randomly from discs showing paths that can be rotated to link with the paths on neighbouring island discs. On their turn players can change paths or rotate any island disc. Pirates automatically move forward if rotating an island disc extends the path the pirate is on, and if they pass over a treasure they’ll pick it up, but end their turn on the same disc as another pirate crew and they’ll be ambushed.

It takes skill to navigate the island, collect all the treasures, and avoid the other pirate crews, but make the right moves and a pirate can travel long distances along the same style of path in their turn.

X Arrr! usually plays in 20-25 minutes. It has simple rules and simple actions but still requires players to think and plan to win the game.

—description from the designer

Caesar: Rome vs. Gaul is a fast-playing, easy-to-learn, two-player card-driven game on Caesar’s conquest of Gaul. One player plays Caesar as he attempts to gain wealth and fame in Gallia at the expense of the Gauls. The other player controls all the independent tribes of Gaul as they slowly awake to the peril of Roman conquest.

Caesar: Rome vs. Gaul uses many of the core rules and systems used in Hannibal: Rome vs. Carthage. Players are dealt 7 cards at the start of each turn and use their cards to move their armies and place control markers. Players familiar with Hannibal: Rome vs. Carthage will quickly learn this game.

The game covers the height of the Gallic Wars, the period between 57 BC and 52 BC when Caesar campaigned back and forth across Gaul putting down one rebellion after another and invading Germania and Britannia. Units are individual Roman Legions or Gallic Tribes. Each turn represents one year.

—description from the publisher

Wobuga comes from WOrd BUilding GAme.

It includes 72 letters: 6 each for A, E, I, O; 4 each for U, Y; 2 each of all other letters.

To start, the letters are stirred face down, and each player draws 5 letters. A turn consists of drawing a letter and then either making a word out of one's hand, or adding one or more letters to words already on the table without rearranging their order. After playing, a player draws again and continues playing until announcing "I am thru", and the turn goes to the left. One can also make a sentence out of their own words, after which those words cannot be further altered. When a turn is over and other players see plays they could have done, they say "Wobuga" and can make the play for them and score the points they could have scored.

Points scored are: 5 points for each letter played during one's turn, 10 points for each word of a sentence, and 25 points for making the word "Wobuga". The highest score when all the letters are used wins.

There is also a solitaire mode where a player takes repeated turns and tries to use all the letters. Also, Wobuga Rush, where two players each play with a half deck in solitaire mode, and play through all their letters. Each player gets 5 points for each letter not used, and -10 points for being the first to say "I am thru"; the lower score wins.

—user summary

Includes a deck of 61 cards having two sets of consonants (42) and three sets of vowels (15) (each letter having a point value), and four wild cards; plus a reference card showing the letter values, and a 1-minute sand timer.

Players have hands of 8 cards. The first player lays down a word from their hand of at least 3 cards. From then on, a turn is made by making a new word using at least one of the cards on the table, and at least on of the cards in the hand (the unused table cards are discarded), and drawing back up to an 8 card hand. The new word's score is the sum of the letter values newly laid down, with the older letters not scoring; except if all the table letters are used then the score is the entire word, doubled; if all the cards in hand are used in the new word the score is the entire word tripled.

The game ends when every player has had an equal number of turns after a player's score reaches a pre-determined total.

The solitaire game has the player playing cards to the table one at a time, either starting a new column (up to 5 columns), or adding a letter to an existing column. Two columns can also be combined end to end. Whenever a column forms a complete word it can be removed. The player wins if they can remove all the cards.

—user summary

Skruuvi is a Finnish relative of Auction Whist (which is essentially Bridge without a dummy).

Like Bridge, it's a four player, partnership trick taking game. Players bid how many of the thirteen tricks their partnership can win (or, unlike Bridge, lose). Also, players can communication information about their hands through their bids (and, unlike Bridge, the cards they can exchange) with a system of conventions. Here are the main differences:


 Players get to exchange cards with each other. There are two ways of playing Skruuvi depending on how players exchange cards: Kitty games and No-kitty games.


- In a Kitty game, players receive 12 cards; the four undealt cards is the kitty. The highest bidder adds the kitty to their hand, then gives any four cards to their partner. The partner adds these cards to their hand, then gives one card to each of the other three players.

- In a No-kitty game, players receive 13 cards. The highest bidder gives any four cards to their partner. The partner adds these cards to their hand, then returns any four cards back to the highest bidder.


 Players optionally play several rounds of Bolshevik, where one player attempts to win or lose all 13 tricks (without a partner).



 Players can bid misere, which is a bid of how many tricks a partnership will lose (without a trump suit).



 As mentioned, there is no dummy!



 As in Bridge, the lowest bid is to win 7 out of the 13 tricks. However, the lowest bid you can win the auction round is 11 tricks! (Or for misere bids, to lose 11 tricks!) In No-kitty games, the lowest bid is to win 12 out of the 13 tricks. 



 A game of Skruuvi lasts 24 rounds. Each player plays with a different partner for 8 rounds each.


—user summary

Tattoo Stories is a drawing party game where your art skills don’t matter. In a series of quick-paced tattoo competitions, win the most points by making up tattoos and telling the best stories. Compete to get your tattoo and story selected. It’s easy to learn, and you’ll be having fun in a matter of 3 minutes. You will be surprised by the creative tattoos and stories you and your friends can make up.

The game includes lots of fun, creative prompts (tattoo elements) to help you design the best tattoo. This game is fun to play with your friends and family. Each player has a dry erase board and marker on which to draw their tattoos. The “customer” chooses five cards, containing tattoo elements that should be included in their tattoo. Then, the “tattoo artists” will have three minutes to ask the customer questions, and create their tattoo. After the three minutes are up, each player will reveal their tattoo to the group, and pitch their tattoo to the customer. The customer awards each individual element card to the person who used it best/most creatively. The player with the most cards after every player has drawn twice wins the game.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

link.value: The United States Playing Card Company

item.description:
It's time for two teams to go head-to-head in a fast and furious game of ridiculous challenges. Jump into the hot seat, flip the timer, and get going!

Choose a player to referee the contest in 20 Second Showdown. Everyone else splits into two teams and sits opposite each other, face-off style. At the beginning of each round, the referee resets the timer with an even amount of "sand" in each half. The referee's job is to read out the challenges and flip the timer, which has twenty seconds of sand in each half. To win, you need to force the other team to run out of "sand" by completing your challenges as quickly as possible. The first team to run out of "sand" loses the round, and the first team to win three rounds is crowned "20-Second Champions".

—description from the publisher

Linkus! is a fast and fun party game based on associations and their interpretations.

In Linkus! players try to connect one picture on the card from his hand with one of the pictures on the card in the center of the table by association link. Each card has 3 different pictures on it. Players must play as fast as they can because time is limited. They play cards in clockwise order turn by turn. Player can not use the same picture that was used by the previous player.

In the game there are two different modes: Competitive and Cooperative. Also you will have 360 unique illustrations to enrich your game experience.

—description from the designer

Mindblock plays similar to Rummikub in that players have a hand of items and want to play them into a common space in sets and runs, with those sets and runs being breakable should you be able to rearrange things in order to play more from your hand.

What's different about Mindblock is that players can stack smaller blocks together in order to use them as a larger number, giving you more play opportunities to get pieces out of your hand.

London, 19th Century: building sites in Kensington district are highly coveted. Each architect wants to build the most impressive, most solid and highest structure. But the competition is fierce. Who will earn the most points with his building and who will convince investors of his luxury mansion?

Players are architects building a Georgian palace taking into account the building regulations. The building parts were drawn from the hidden deck in the center of the player board or from a warehouse, either your own or from your opponents.

A game ends when the seventh roof tile with a bird is drawn. Then each architect is allowed to build the tiles left in his warehouse.

To win the game, players should consider the amount of roofed windows and doors as well as different heights. Cats will also earn points for the final tallying. Well done and congratulations to the best architect!

—description from the publisher (translated)

About: In Cyber Siege everyone is a hacker trying to gain control of the system through use of programs, once you have uploaded or install all your bytes of data to the system you have taken control. Cyber Siege is a game that uses temporary alliances, strategy, and program actions to advance your own agenda, or slow down your opponents. Discussion, deals, persuasion, and even temporary treaties are allowed and encouraged. Turns are fast in this game and everyone stays engages the whole game. The rules are simple to understand but there is still strategic depth. Players will attempt to take control of Programs by installing more bytes of data then their opponents.

Victory Condition: Be the first player to Upload or Install all your bytes of data from your hard drive into the System!

Game Play: 
Cyber Siege consists of several game rounds separated into three phases:

 Install Phase: Players take turns installing bytes of data into one of many programs in order to take majority control and take the programs action.
 Execution Phase: Players take turns executing programs. Each program has a special ability that either helps yourself or hurts one of your opponents. But because the scoring is hidden no one knows for sure who is winning, therefor deflection and collusion to change who to attack is an open table discussion.
 Packet Generation Phase: Players simultaneously generate there data packet (the number of bytes of data they will get to install on the following round) based upon the actions executed by the program.




—description from the publisher

Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable
